title: Acacia viscidula
text:
Acacia viscidula, also known as sticky wattle, is a shrub of the genus "<a href="Acacia">Acacia</a>" and the subgenus "Plurinerves" that is <a href="endemism">endemic</a> to an area of eastern <a href="Australia">Australia</a>.
Description.
The shrub typically grows to a height of or occasionally to and a width of about and has an erect or spreading habit with smooth, grey or grey-brown coloured bark and angled to flattened, resinous and hairy branchlets that have ribbed. Like most species of "Acacia" it has <a href="phyllode">phyllode</a>s rather than true leaves. The ascending, thin, hairy or <a href="Glabrousness%20%28botany%29">glabrous</a> and evergreen phyllodes have a linear shape that can be slightly incurved with a length of and a width of and have three to seven impressed, distant and resinous nerves. It blooms between August and October producing simple <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a>s that occur singly or in pairs in the <a href="axil">axil</a>s with spherical flower-heads that have a diameter of and contain 15 to 35 light to bright yellow coloured flowers. The firmly papery and hairy <a href="seed%20pod">seed pod</a>s that form after flowering are usually straight but can be slightly curved and are raised alternately over each of the seeds and sometimes a little constricted between some seeds. The pods have a length of and a width of and contain longitudinally arranged seeds.
Taxonomy.
The species was first formally described by the botanist <a href="George%20Bentham">George Bentham</a> in 1842 as a part of the <a href="William%20Jackson%20Hooker">William Jackson Hooker</a> work "Notes on Mimoseae, with a synopsis of species" as published in the "London Journal of Botany". It was reclassified as "Racosperma viscidulum" in 1987 by <a href="Leslie%20Pedley">Leslie Pedley</a> then transferred back to genus "Acacia" in 2006. The <a href="botanical%20name">specific epithet</a> is in reference to the sticky or viscid nature of the plant. It has a similar appearance to "<a href="Acacia%20lanigera">Acacia lanigera</a>" which is found further south and also resembles "<a href="Acacia%20dawsonii">Acacia dawsonii</a>".
Distribution.
The is found in the <a href="Darling%20Downs">Darling Downs</a> region of south eastern <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a> and eastern parts of <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a>. In Queensland the range extends as far west as <a href="Injune%2C%20Queensland">Injune</a> and in New South Wales as far west as around <a href="Coonabarabran%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Coonabarabran</a> where it is found un upland areas with <a href="granite">granite</a> based soils and is usually a part of low woodland communities along with species of "<a href="Eucalyptus">Eucalyptus</a>" and other "Acacias". In New South Wales it is mostly located in the <a href="Tablelands%20Region">Tablelands Region</a> from around <a href="Tamworth%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Tamworth</a> in the south out to <a href="Mount%20Kaputar%20National%20Park">Mount Kaputar National Park</a> in the west and to around <a href="Tenterfield%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Tenterfield</a> in the west where it is usually part of dry <a href="sclerophyll%20forest">sclerophyll forest</a> communities or among the heath in crevices of granite outcrops.
Cultivation.
The plant is available commercially in seedling or in seed form. The seeds have to be treated with boiling water before sowing. Growing by <a href="Plant%20propagation">propagation</a> of cuttings should be possible. It is useful as a screen or as an informal hedge. It can be quite dense making it a suitable nesting sites for small native birds. It is fast growing, will tolerate full sun or partial shade, can tolerate a light <a href="frost">frost</a>, is <a href="drought">drought</a> tolerant once established and prefers well-drained soil.
